title: Majestic Thiruvalluvar Statue, Vivekananda Memorial and Karumariamman Temple
text:
Majestic Thiruvalluvar Statue, Vivekananda Memorial and Karumariamman Temple Majestic Thiruvalluvar Statue, Vivekananda Memorial and Karumariamman Temple 0 
Kanyakumari is one of the most unique tourist destinations in India where one can visualize the splendid and mesmerizing view of the merging point of two seas and an ocean- the Bay of Bengal, the Arabian Sea and the Indian Ocean. One can clearly differentiate these three water bodies by its unique color. Kanyakumari is not only a popular tourist destination, but the Hindus considered Kanyakumari as a holy pilgrimage as the nomenclature of this place was done in the name of famous temple of goddess Devi Kanya Kumari Amman. Kanyakumari, the southernmost district of India, is located in the state of Tamil Nadu, plays a major role in south India tourism. While holidaying at Kanyakumari one should not miss the opportunity to visit famous Kumari Amman temple, gigantic Thiruvalluvar Statue and majestic Vivekananda Rock Memorial. 
Gigantic Thiruvalluvar Statue: The Thiruvalluvar Statue is famous for its glory of being a massive and captivated structure; stands on a small rock island of Kanyakaumari, which is only 400 meters away from the coastline and well connected by ferry services. This 133 feet (40.6 m) heighted statue was carved by renowned Indian sculptor Dr. V. Ganapati Sthapati, which epitomizes an elevated massive structure of the great Tamil poet, author and philosopher Thirukkural. The actual height of the statue is 95 feet which stands on a 38 feet 3 tier pedestal and the combined height is 133 feet. The statue carries a weight of 7000 tons. 
The 3 tier foundation identified as Atharapeedam which is encircled by Mandapa (also known as Alankara Mandapam). Ten elephant statues are surrounding the Alankara Mandapam which represents eight directions with earth and space. 140 steps are erected inside the Mandapa, which tourists consider and worship as the holy feet of Thiruvalluvar. The stony pedestal of the statue signifies "pleasures" and "wealth" and defines that wealth and love can be earned by the foundation of strong virtue. One can see the alluring Vivekananda Rock memorial from this statue. 
Alluring Vivekananda Rock memorial: Vivekananda Rock Memorial is famous for its calm and serene atmosphere. It was constructed in the year 1970, under the supervision of Shri Eknath Ranade, to honor the visit of the great spiritual educator and Prophet Swami Vivekananda in the month of December 1982. It was said that in the search of peace and enlightenment, Swamiji came to Kanyakumari and seated on the rock for deep meditation for a continuous period of three days and got the enlightenment. As per the mythological belief, it is said that the rock has been blessed by the touch of 'the holy feet' of the Devi Kumari and a similar human feet, slight brownish in color has been established here as the symbol of Shripadam. 
Vivekananda Rock Memorial is the most popular tourist attraction for its purity and sacredness. A massive statue of Swami Vivekananda is seen here. The cenotaph is having two major structures- Shripada Mandapam and the Vivekananda Mandapam. The main temple is found in Shripada Mandapam and a Meditation hall is constructed in Vivekananda Mandapam, which is also known as Dhyana Mandapam. Travellers can experience a relaxing and stimulating meditation in the completely dark and peaceful room where "Om' chanting is continuously been articulated. Visitor can be enthralled by the breathtaking view of the assimilation of three major water bodies namely Bay of Bengal, Arabian Sea and Indian Ocean from this rock. 
Holy Kummari Amman Temple: Ones Kanyakumari pilgrimage will be incomplete without visiting the holy Kumari Amman temple. The divine temple is 3000 year old and is devoted to sacred and virgin Goddess Kanya Kumari. In this temple, the idol of the goddess is east facing and the key entry is through the Northern gate and the Eastern gate remains closed most of the times except some festivals. There was a mythological story of goddess Kanya Kumari, once the demon king got power over Devas and started exploiting and punishing Devas. Devas accomplished Yagna to defeat the evil power! Goddess Parasakthi came to Kumari in the form of a virgin girl and initiated her penance. Then, when Banusura tried to win the Goddess by his power, she slaughtered him with her Chakragudha, and released the Devas from miseries. 
After entering through the Northern gate, visitors stroll around the outer corridor and visit the Navaratri Mandapam and then move to the second corridor where after praying to the Kala Bhairava, the disciples reach to the Dhwajastambha and devotees can get a clear view of goddess Devi Kanya Kumari. After adoring the Goddess, visitors arrive at the inner corridor, where they can have the darshana of Indra Vinayak. A small monument is also found; dedicated to Tyaga Sundari. The Devi looks like an attractive young girl, pose with a rosary in her right hand, and glittering nose jewellery with shimmering radiance, made up of Blue stone. It is said that Devi's sparkling nose ring is made up of Ruby as its brightness can be seen from far. Visitors are being asked to contribute â‚¹10 as a donation to enter the inner area, where photography is strictly prohibited and men have to remove their shirts and wear a traditional costume before entering the temple. Along with all the pilgrimages, Kanyakumari is the place where one can enjoy and things to do in Kanyakumari , the mesmerizing and spellbinding sunrise and sunset. Kanyakumari district enjoys a diverse landscape with sea on three sides and the elevations of the Western Ghats surrounded the northern side. The district is encircled by Tirunelveli District on the North and the east; Gulf of Mannar at the South eastern part and the South and the South West part is bounded by the Indian Ocean and the Arabian Sea.
